subject: Re: [junit] Test Case Results segregation
msgSnippet: ... I think I understand. You want to be able to run, for example, only the tests I added in the last 2 hours . If you are running JDK 5.0, you can do this

ramandeep singh wrote:
> 
> Hi,
> Thanks for the reply.
> 
> Different version means.
> A test function is added to a test class and
> thereby upgrades the version to a new no.
> There are other functions in the same class
> which belong to previous version. The idea is
> to segregate which methods were recently added.
> 
> So far so good I have been able to use a doclet to
> extract these methods using the @since javadoc tag.
> This doclet has the logic to segregate these methods.
> 
> Now how do I integrate this with Junit.
> Any suggestions?

I think I understand. You want to be able to run, for example, "only the 
tests I added in the last 2 hours".

If you are running JDK 5.0, you can do this with attributes and by using 
GSBase's RecursiveTestSuite or JUnit-addons' DirectorySuiteBuilder. Each 
of these allows you to filter out tests on any criteria you want -- you 
could ignore tests that don't have the right attribute.

Other than that, you'd have to use naming conventions or do what you've 
been doing.

If you only want to separate test case classes from one another, you 
could implement tag interfaces. This is essentially the same solution as 
attributes, but you cannot use it at the method level.

So you'll likely either maintain the version numbers in the code using 
XDoclet, or in a separate file for which you could write a simple 
TestSuite collector.
--
